Award.AwardTitle: CRII: ACI: 4D Dynamic Anisotropic Meshing and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is an emerging need in healthcare, transportation, and simulation areas to realistically reconstruct, visualize, and capture space-time (4D) models/images (dynamic objects) from a complicated scenario in real-time. For example, high-fidelity dynamically modeling and visualizing 4D deformable shapes and variations of organs and their surrounding tissues in real-time become important for building an effective 4D model planning/capturing for radiation therapy (e.g., 4D-Doctor system). It requires dynamic anisotropic modeling and multi-modality imaging techniques for accurate registration, segmentation, and visualization. The goal of this project is to develop a tool for efficiently computing high-quality 4D dynamic anisotropic meshing models for complicated 4D objects with features and details in the large-scale volume image data. This project involves several disciplines, such as geometric modeling, computer graphics, and medical image processing, and has a potential to provide a high-quality platform for both interdisciplinary research and education integration. This project will aim to enrich the computer science and engineering curriculum at Wayne State University in both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Therefore, this research aligns with the NSF mission to promote the progress of science and to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

A theoretical and computational framework for 4D dynamic anisotropic meshing with high quality and efficiency is essential for tackling challenges in efﬁciently representing and capturing the 4D data. The key strength of this project focuses on the transformative research ideas and approaches in particle-based approach for Riemannian metric mesh modeling, serving as a foundation for geometry-guided 3D/4D imaging informatics. The proposed exploratory research activities will address the following major themes and objectives: (1) to develop a novel particle-based method for high-quality 3D and 4D anisotropic tetrahedral meshing; (2) to evaluate the mesh quality and apply the proposed theoretical meshing approaches in applications to medical imaging, and develop a testbed system to evaluate its capability and potential in 4D-Doctor system, including 4D image registration and segmentation. The unified theoretical particle-based meshing framework, integrating Gaussian energy, dynamic Riemannian metrics, and high-dimensional embedding theory, can enable efficient generation of dynamic anisotropic meshes from a brand new perspective. This research initiative is innovative as it will establish a novel geometric modeling framework supporting 3D/4D imaging informatics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
***General intellectual merit and broader of impacts:

There is an emerging need in healthcare, transportation, and simulation areas to realistically reconstruct, visualize, and capture space-time (4D) models/images (dynamic objects) from a complicated scenario in real-time. For example, high-fidelity modeling and visualizing 4D deformable shapes and variations of organs and their surrounding tissues in real-time become important for building an effective 4D model planning/capturing for radiation therapy. The key strength of this project focuses on the transformative research ideas and approaches in particle-based approach for anisotropic tetrahedral mesh modeling, serving as a foundation for geometry-guided 3D/4D imaging informatics. The proposed method will have impact on various applications, such as 4D image/shape registration, segmentation, and reconstruction.

 

***Summary of outcomes of publications:

Research results are 1 book, 13 journal papers, and 7 conference papers in total during the project years. They are either published in top conference proceedings (e.g., SIGGRAPH, SIGGRAPH Asia, VIS, MICCAI, ACM MM, CVPR, ICCV, SGP, GMP, etc.) and presented in professional conferences, or top journals (e.g., ACM TOG, IEEE TVCG, CAGD, CGF, Scientific Reports - Nature, Physics in Medicine and Biology, etc.) as well as a book (Elsevier). This project has been worked on by five Ph.D. students, three Research Opportunities for Engineering Undergraduates Awardees, and two M.S. students from the PI's research group at Wayne State University.

 

Book:

Key outcomes on 3D / 4D geometric modeling:

* Jing Hua, Jiaxi Hu, Zichun Zhong, "Spectral Geometry of Shapes: Principles and Applications," in Academic Press, Elsevier, 2019.

 

Journal and conference papers:

Key outcomes on 3D / 4D anisotropic meshings:

* Saifeng Ni, Zichun Zhong, Yang Liu, Wenping Wang, Zhonggui Chen, Xiaohu Guo, "Sliver-Suppressing Tetrahedral Mesh Optimization with Gradient-Based Shape Matching Energy," Computer-Aided Geometric Design (GMP 2017), Vol. 52-53, pp. 247 - 261, 2017.

* Zichun Zhong, Wenping Wang, Bruno Levy, Jing Hua, Xiaohu Guo, "Computing a High-Dimensional Euclidean Embedding from an Arbitrary Smooth Riemannian Metric," ACM TOG (SIGGRAPH 2018), Vol. 37, Issue 4, Article No. 62, 2018.

* Saifeng Ni, Zichun Zhong, Jin Huang, Wenping Wang, Xiaohu Guo, "Field-Aligned and Lattice-Guided Tetrahedral Meshing," Computer Graphics Forum (SGP 2018), Vol. 37, No. 5, pp. 161 - 172, 2018.

* Sikai Zhong, Zichun Zhong, Jing Hua, "Surface Reconstruction by Parallel and Unified Particle-Based Resampling from Point Clouds," Computer-Aided Geometric Design (GMP 2019), Vol. 71, pp. 43 - 62, 2019.

* Hajar Hamidian, Zichun Zhong, Farshad Fotouhi, Jing Hua, "Surface Registration with Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors," IEEE TVCG, 2019.

* Yifan Wang, Zichun Zhong, Jing Hua, "DeepOrganNet: On-the-Fly Reconstruction and Visualization of 3D / 4D Lung Models from Single-View Projections by Deep Deformation Network," IEEE TVCG (IEEE SciVis 2019), Vol. 26, No. 1, pp. 960 - 970, 2020.

* Yifan Wang, Guoli Yan, Haikuan Zhu, Sagar Buch, Ying Wang, Ewart Mark Haacke, Jing Hua, Zichun Zhong, "VC-Net: Deep Volume-Composition Networks for Segmentation and Visualization of Highly Sparse and Noisy Image Data," IEEE TVCG (IEEE SciVis 2020).

* Guoxin Fang, Tianyu Zhang, Sikai Zhong, Xiangjia Chen, Zichun Zhong, Charlie C. L. Wang, "Reinforced FDM: Multi-Axis Filament Alignment with Controlled Anisotropic Strength," ACM TOG (SIGGRAPH Asia 2020).

 

Outcomes on 3D computer vision:

* Haotian Xu, Ming Dong, Zichun Zhong, "Directionally Convolutional Networks for 3D Shape Segmentation," ICCV, 2017.

* Artem Komarichev, Zichun Zhong, Jing Hua, "A-CNN: Annularly Convolutional Neural Networks on Point Clouds," CVPR, 2019.

* Elaheh Barati, Xuewen Chen, Zichun Zhong, "Attention-Based Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-View Environments," AAMAS, 2019.

* Yankun Xi, Guoli Yan, Jing Hua, Zichun Zhong, "JointFontGAN: Joint Geometry-Content GAN for Font Generation via Few-Shot Learning," ACM Multimedia, 2020.

 

Selected outcomes on medical applications:

* Xin Zhen, Jiawei Chen, Zichun Zhong, et al., "Deep Convolutional Neural Network with Transfer Learning for Rectum Toxicity Prediction in Cervical Cancer Radiotherapy: A Feasibility Study," Physics in Medicine and Biology, Vol. 62, No. 21, pp. 8246 - 8263, 2017 (Editor's Choice).

* Xin Zhen, Jiawei Chen, Zichun Zhong, et al., "Transfer Learning Using Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for Rectum Toxicity Prediction in Cervical Cancer Radiotherapy," AAPM, 2017 (Science Council Session Award).

* Haibin Chen, Zichun Zhong, Yiwei Yang, et al., "Internal Motion Estimation by Internal-external Motion Modeling for Lung Cancer Radiotherapy," Scientific Reports - Nature, Vol. 8, Article number: 3677, 2018.

* Jiawei Chen, Haibin Chen, Zichun Zhong, et al., "Investigating Rectal Toxicity Associated Dosimetric Features with Deformable Accumulated Rectal Surface Dose Maps for Cervical Cancer Radiotherapy," Radiation Oncology, Vol. 13, No. 125, pp. 1 - 10, 2018.

* Yifan Wang, Guoli Yan, Haikuan Zhu, Sagar Buch, Ying Wang, Ewart Mark Haacke, Jing Hua, Zichun Zhong, "JointVesselNet: Joint Volume-Projection Convolutional Embedding Networks for 3D Cerebrovascular Segmentation," MICCAI, 2020.
